context: Anybody else think that we are taking A.I. way too far??

replies.context: Yup. This stuff is only getting cheaper too. What if it fell into the hands of our enemy.

context:
Ummm this stuff has been around for decades. Back when I was in in the 90's.
Nothing new here. I guess new to the public?

replies.context: Thanks.

context: Just wait... Somebody's going to hack one of those things and start their own little war.

The Navy had a remote controller Destroyer in the early 1990's. I worked with that project for 3 years as an active duty Sailor working along side an array of very talented government engineers and other folks from various defense contractors etc.. 
Freaking amazing stuff for the time. Our main purpose was to test shipboard self defense weapon systems. What a blast that was.

replies.context: Remote is different than A.I.

context: Autonomous...or Remote Controlled?

replies.context: I'm ok with human controlled drones...  but not A.I.
Skynet has become aware.

context: Great. Skynet is upon us. We have to deal with AOC and now this? Just what we needed.

replies.context: Actually.. When AI realizes the danger that is AOC; it will act accordingly, no?
One can hope but these are unpredictable complex systems.  Red Cortez might turn on the AI.

context: Some think it is great news we are coming up with a defense to counter the threat of swarm attacks--- Personally i think it is great (actually, AWESOME!) that in doing so we have come up with our our fleet of autonomous swarming attack boats!

replies.context: Machines that are programmed to kill humans...  Yeah, nothing could possibly go wrong there...

There are a lot of machines out there that could kill humans if something went wrong (and it happens often). Because people saw Terminator one time is not a good reason not to develop our military tech. You create safeguards and protocols with the machinery, just as you would with any other potentially dangerous non-military machinery. 

Frankly, I am more concerned about the pack of human-piloted machines swarmed around me on the highway, then I am about the pack of autonomous machines swarming in some distant ocean on our enemies doorstep.
Call me old fashioned...  I don't trust machines...
Well to each their own. I can't argue with a luddite

I'm not a Luddite, I'm just against tech thinking for itself...  You apparently don't take everything into account...  Hacking, Viruses, Malfunctions, all of which can alter the programming of this self aware machines...  Friendly Fire is horrible, imagine an Army of self aware war machines being hacked and now our Army turns against us because the Chinese has better hackers...  I'm all for new tech, just not self aware tech.

None of this scares me as much a nuke being dropped by a human with a short temper and an itchy trigger finger, so I don't see the point in worrying over it. 

As it stands these gun boats aren't AI. They are just remote controlled boats ("autonomous")
Well, then...  This debate is over.  I have no problem with Remote Controlled...

context: Why does it still have seats??

replies.context: Is it VENi or WENi?
In 2019 Veni

context:
As cool as this all seems it's decidedly uncool. The implications of where were headed is scary as f. Soon humanity won't be necessary at all for the elite to accomplish whatever it is they want to accomplish and all this tech is doing nothing but giving them 100% control over us. 
This won't be like the movies. The only way to be free of these people will be to take out satellites - a nearly impossible task for the common man. 

We're not going to like where all this leads.

replies.context: yep, indirect observation on just basic employment.  Kind of related to what you are pointing out.  This "AI" stuff has SERIOUS implications for just about every and all JOBS you can dream up, as far as eventual replacement of HUMAN labor.  Not today, not next year, but once it starts to cascade, it could be interesting times, for certain.  The reality is we are ALREADY seeing it's effects today, but its still relatively minor enough to be subtle and blend in with the background noise.  But it's coming, and the driver is ALWAYS green...

context:
Skynet?  Is that you?

All kidding aside, check out the video on General Dynamics' Atlas robot does parkour.  Can you imagine having 10,000 of those things coming at you?  Big nope.............

what people dont seem to realize is that a boat without an operator can do a lot more high speed maneuvers.  mount a few say TOW missles on it and zig zag in close and put a few big holes at the water line of the enemy.
Very cool.  They should practice on sea pirates!

Isn't this the same kind of boat that surrendered to the Iranian speedboats w/o firing a shot, and then apologized for getting in their way?   The others had sailors on them.   This one is better equipped w/o actual Navy men to surrender.  The Iranians got the other boat.  This one can sink itself with a remote controlled white flag.

replies.context: Let me guess... You never served?
Served?  Yes.  Surrendered?  No.

context: It's amazing what the US military can develop when properly funded.
All fun and games until the defender hacks the algorithem and redirects the swarm back to attack the host.

replies.context: That is the by far biggest concern I personally have. Must find a way to hackproof these buggers!

context: Think the navy needs to bring back PT Boats or PRB's?   lol
Judgement day.  Just around the corner.

replies.context: In 12 years according to the newly elected congress woman......

context: pilotless boats seems alot less risky than cars, trucks or airplanes.  Sounds like a natural.
It's all fun and games until Skynet becomes self aware!
This type of warfare is just fine.  However we need way more training for when the power does go out.  Recommend reading the books Ghost Fleet and One Second After.
I'm for any technology that puts more distance between our Warriors and harm.

I've always thought that we should be looking into using  arial drones to jam enemy radar.  Launch a couple hundred high radar profile drones ahead of an attack and while the enemy would know that an attack was coming, any radar based defenses would be rendered useless.  The background clutter such a swarm would cause would enhance our stealth units ability to get in closer and be more effective.
This is going to be a cluster...
AI war fighting machines. Lets hope they one day don't decide to stop killing other machines and turn on us.

replies.context:
using current tech video games as a model, I'll be doubling up on body armor in the event of "friendly crossfire". We'll still need humans in the loop as it is not going to be what I would call difficult to spoof a friendly unit, unless they go for the "no mans land" sceanrio where these bots just destroy anything that they find.

In a naval encounter, I'd like to bring 100 barrels to bear on a target without risking 400 men.

next big thing will be directed energy weapons, rail guns and the like have a place, but we need a more shall you say, global solution
Step away from the TV. Meet people. Discover reality, it's fun!

context: I'm guessing that each one of these cost about $100,000,000. About the same as a F-35. The Navy will be able add 10 to the fleet in about 10 years.

replies.context: Always guessing. Yup.

context: Seems like AI controlled swarms are the big thing. But probably have already been around for a few decades if we're being honest.
I hope these developments recognize that greater dependence upong electronics and communications will spur greater efforts to target and deploy EMP weaponry, both tactical and regionally applied.

replies.context: Yeah, you kinds hope they have thought of that.  But you never really know.
We already shield communications equipment from EMP.
